statement.text: Atrophie blanche refers to stellate white scarred areas of atrophic skin surrounded by telangiectasia and hyperpigmentation at the ankle, representing end-stage venous skin damage with loss of capillaries and high ulceration risk.

explanation.intuition: These white patches are essentially skin that has lost its blood supply - scarred areas where the tiny blood vessels have died off. The white color is because there's no blood flow to the skin in these spots anymore.
explanation.key_insight: Atrophie blanche represents irreversible capillary loss. These areas are extremely fragile with minimal capacity to heal. Even minor trauma can cause ulceration that is very difficult to heal. It is classified as CEAP C4b.
explanation.technical_details: Appearance: ivory-white atrophic plaques, often stellate or irregular, surrounded by telangiectasia and hemosiderin staining. Histology: loss of capillaries, epidermal atrophy, dermal sclerosis. Location: ankle and lower leg (gaiter area). CEAP: C4b. Etiology: end-stage venous disease, also seen in livedoid vasculopathy (different mechanism). Management: compression, avoid trauma, treat underlying reflux. Prognosis: high ulcer risk, poor healing.

clinical_features.appearance: White, atrophic, stellate plaques surrounded by telangiectasia and hyperpigmentation
clinical_features.pathology: Capillary loss with epidermal atrophy and dermal sclerosis
clinical_features.clinical_significance: Extremely fragile - high risk for ulceration with minimal trauma
clinical_features.differential: Livedoid vasculopathy (different mechanism but similar appearance)

clinical_pearls: White color indicates complete loss of capillary blood supply
Extremely fragile - counsel patients to protect from trauma
Often coexists with lipodermatosclerosis and hyperpigmentation
